item.title: Government shutdowns usually have little economic impact. This time could be different
item.description: For all the political firestorms they generate, government shutdowns have been nonevents for both markets and the economy.

item.title: Labor Dept. won't release Friday's key jobs report, other data if government shuts down
item.description: The department is preparing for what would amount to a news and data blackout should the government suspend operations.

item.title: A possible risk to markets from a shutdown getting chatter on trading floors
item.description: Wall Street is questioning some of the tail risk from a government shutdown and how it might differ from what's happened in prior closures.

item.title: The UK's finance minister keeps public guessing over tax hikes
item.description: Reeves remains tight-lipped about the forthcoming Autumn Budget, at which economists expect her to announce tax hikes.

item.title: The resilient stock market may be keeping the economy out of a recession. Why that's a bad thing
item.description: Consumers with larger stock holdings are feeling fine, while those with smaller or no holdings are not.
